dt: {bc}to supersede (another) especially by force or treachery
{bc}to take the place of and serve as a substitute for especially by reason of superior excellence or power

pt: {sc}replace{/sc} {sc}displace{/sc} {sc}supplant{/sc} {sc}supersede{/sc} mean to put out of a usual or proper place or into the place of another. {sc}replace{/sc} implies a filling of a place once occupied by something lost, destroyed, or no longer usable or adequate.
{sc}supplant{/sc} implies either a dispossessing or usurping of another's place, possessions, or privileges or an uprooting of something and its replacement with something else.

pt.t: was abruptly {it}supplanted{/it} in her affections by another

pt: {sc}supersede{/sc} implies replacing a person or thing that has become superannuated, obsolete, or otherwise inferior.

pt.t: the new edition {it}supersedes{/it} all previous ones

et: Middle English, from Anglo-French {it}supplanter{/it}, from Latin {it}supplantare{/it} to trip up, cause to stumble, from {it}sub-{/it} + {it}planta{/it} sole of the foot {ma}{mat|place|}{/ma}
shortdef: to supersede (another) especially by force or treachery
to eradicate and supply a substitute for
